abstracts.cdata!:
The Santo Domingo Municipality Technical
            Assistance Project for the Dominican Republic was approved
            in May 1983, became effective in November 1983, and was
            cancelled in July 1984. There were no disbursements under
            the loan except for the front-end fee. A Bank supervision
            mission in November 1983 detected a basic loss of commitment
            on the part of the Central Government toward the strict
            financial measures required at the local level. Without
            those measures, attainment of project objectives was
            jeopardized. In January 1984, the Government confirmed the
            municipality's inability to provide counterpart funds.
            In February 1984, the municipality requested that the loan
            be cancelled for macroeconomic reasons. Although the Bank
            did not discount the country's difficult macroeconomic
            situation, it felt that political considerations were more
            to blame for the project's demise. The project called
            for a disciplined approach to municipal management. The loan
            agreement contained covenants requiring stricter enforcement
            of land tax and other financial and accounting measures.
            Also, the project supported a reduction in the city's
            blue collar workforce. The Bank concluded that the project
            was too politically sensitive to be implemented. As a result
            of cancellation, the project's institutional impact was
            nil and there were no benefits to be sustained. The overall
            project rating is unsatisfactory. No audit is planned. The
            Bank's experience with this project illustrates the
            pitfalls of attempting to deal with a Government
            characterized by highly centralized decision making, lack of
            clear economic policy, uncertain commitment to reform, and
            weak institutional capacity. The Bank has learned to move
            cautiously in the Dominican Republic.
